sections.purpose: To describe the standard operating procedure for the operation of Colloid Mill for fine dispersion, emulsification, and homogenization of pharmaceutical suspensions, emulsions, and semi-solid preparations.
sections.scope: Applicable to milling and homogenization activities carried out in the Pharmaceutics.
procedure: Ensure the colloid mill is installed on a stable foundation with proper alignment.
Verify that all electrical connections and cooling water supply are connected.
Check that the rotor and stator are properly installed with appropriate gap setting.
Verify that the feeding hopper, milling chamber, and discharge outlet are clean.
Power ON the colloid mill and allow it to run empty briefly to check operation.
Set the rotor-stator gap according to desired particle size (smaller gap = finer particles).
Prepare the coarse suspension or pre-mix to be processed.
If required, pre-mix ingredients using a low-shear mixer before colloid milling.
Pour the material into the feeding hopper at a controlled rate.
Start the feed pump or allow gravity feeding as per equipment design.
Monitor the feed rate to maintain consistent flow without overloading.
Observe the discharge for uniform particle size and consistency.
If recirculation is needed, collect the discharge and pass through mill again.
Monitor the motor load and temperature during operation.
Adjust feed rate or gap setting if product consistency is not satisfactory.
Continue processing until desired particle size and uniformity is achieved.
For emulsions, verify phase stability and droplet size of the product.
After completion, stop the feed and allow the mill to run until empty.
Flush the mill with solvent or water to remove residual product.
Dismantle the rotor and stator for thorough cleaning.
Clean all product contact parts and reassemble for next use.
Document milling parameters, gap settings, and product characteristics in the batch record.
precautions: Never operate the mill without proper lubrication and cooling.
Ensure proper rotor-stator gap to prevent metal-to-metal contact.
Do not process materials containing hard particles that can damage surfaces.
Monitor temperature continuously to prevent product degradation.
Use appropriate feed rate to avoid overloading the motor.
Wear hearing protection as colloid mills generate significant noise.
Never insert hands or objects into the mill during operation.
Ensure proper grounding and electrical safety.
Wear appropriate PPE including safety goggles, gloves, and apron.
Follow lockout/tagout procedures during cleaning and maintenance.
